Feb. 8, 1958

div1.p: I will be out your way again before long for a good visit, and I will have much to report to you; during the week past I was out of town on a business trip to Denver, Colo., and Omaha, Nebraska.

In the evenings, I browzedbrowsed through the western collections in both libraries, and to my amazement and delight uncovered real ore; i.e. the accounts of eye-witnesses to the last days of Crazy Horse. Reading these eye-witness accounts was like rolling back the years and living over again those exciting days; days when reason seemed to have fled from the minds of men, when truth went underground and fear and jealousy, treachery and cowardice rode like the four horse-men.

And like a magnet I searched the records and found this from the testimony of Dr. V. T. McGillycuddy, army surgeon, agent at Red Clojud agency later: page 40 of Wes Nebraska History Magazine as follows: (McGillycuddy writing)

.."It was then 5 p.m. and he (C.H.) died about 11:30 p.m. During the evening and at his death there were present Capt. Kennington, officer of the day; LIEUTENANT LEMLHY, special officer of the gyuard; John Provost, interpreter; Touch-The-Clouds, relative of the mother of C.H.; the old father of the chief, 80 years old; and myself."
In all the data I read, this was the first specifc reference to Lemly's presence there; excluding of course his own testimony in his article "The Passing of Crazy Horse."

The actors and events leading up to the death of Crazy Horse in my mind form a tragic Greek drama in which fate and the tides project men onward to a definite course unknowing. The agony of this man in his death symbolizes the death of an age, of a race, of an old world; and the birth of a new; a wstrange new world for a people now without a leader to guide them.
The spirit that breathed so fiercly strongly in that slim frame was freed in death to go to a world in which the physical walls and time no longer constrained it.

Only McGillycuddy really seemed to understand this strange man of the Oglallas; (I mean of the white men present there). He says: "Crazy Horse, but 36 years of age at death, did not have his equal as a warrior and leading chief.... Crazy Horse was a mystic and was revered and feared by all."

Misunderstood and misinterpreted; isn't that the fate of many great men who rise above their fellows. And the jealousy of the others, Red Cloud and Spotted Tail, reminds me of the triumvirate, OctaviousOctavius CaeserCaesar, Mark Antony and Ptolemy or Julius CaeserCaesar, Brutus and CasiusCassius (I am not spelling them correctly).

In any event, after reading the records, I come back to your epic poem with fresh appreciation for its accuracy, for treating the story as ageless drama and tragedy. The actors are the same performing on the Greek stage 3000 years ago; the plot is the same, only the names are different.
I have much more to report and will write in more detail later.
